ost_step.2: He gets a loan for 40% of this value which means (40/100)*$250,000 = $100,000.
ost_step.3: Out of this amount, he used 60% or ($100,000*60/100) = $60,000 to clear up his existing debts.

0.user_question: John decides to get a loan by mortgaging his home.  His house is worth $250,000.  He gets a loan worth 40% of that.  He uses 60% of that to pay off his debts.  How much money did he have leftover after paying debt?

ost_step.2: He gets a loan for 40% of this value which means (40/100)*$250,000 = $100,000.

direct_answer.text: He used 60% of this loan amount ($100,000) to pay off his debts so (60/100)*$100,000=$60,000 was spent. This leaves him with $100,000-$60,000= \$40,000 as leftover cash. Hence, \$\(40,000\) remained after settling all dues..

0.user_question: John decides to get a loan by mortgaging his home.  His house is worth $250,000.  He gets a loan worth 40% of that.  He uses 60% of that to pay off his debts.  How much money did he have leftover after paying debt?

direct_answer.text: Firstly we need to calculate what percentage (in terms of dollar amount) was used as loans. We know it’s up to 40%, so this would mean ($250,000*40%) which equals $100,000. Next, let us find out what percentile part goes towards repayment; here its stated to be 60%. This means multiplying first our initial value obtained above i.e., $100,000*60%= $60,000. That leaves him with $100,000-$60,000=$40,000 remaining funds available within these parameters. The answer is: $40,000.

Next we need to figure out what amount constitutes as part payment towards his existing loans which amounts to (60/100)*$100,000=$60,000 . Hence subtracting this value from the initial amount provides us with ($100,000-$60,000)= $40,000 remaining post settling up any dues related to the property via said lien facility.. Therefore ,the correct choice here would be   option C i.e.,$40,000.

ost_step.2: John received a loan equal to 40% of the value of his house. This means he got a loan for $$250,000*40\%$$ or $100,000.

direct_answer.text: He spent 60% of the loan to pay off his debts so let us find out how much was utilised here; $$\frac{60}{100}\times \$100,000=\$60,000.$$ Since he took a loan ,he still needs to repay it back leaving him with lesser cash thus calculating accordingly ; $$\text {Remaining balance}= \text{Original Loan}-\text{Amount Spent}$$ Substituting values results into :- $$\begin{align*} & \text{Loan} - (\text{%Utilised})\left(\text{loan}\right)\\ &\implies \$100,000-\left(\frac{\text{utilised}}{\text{original}}\)\$100,000\times  60\\ &= \$100,000-(0.6\times 100,000) \\ &= \$100,000-60,000\\ &=\$40,000.\end{align*}$$ Hence,the required numerical solution/answer would be $\boxed{\$40,000}$.

First, we need to find out how much loan value is derived from mortgaging his house. Since the original price of the house is $250,000 and the loan represents 40% of this amount, we can calculate the loan as follows:
Loan Amount = Original Price × Loan Percentage
Loan Amount = $250,000 × 0.40 = $100,000
So, Oliver took out a loan of $100,000 to buy additional equipment for his business.
